segments.text: My name is Elizabeth and I'm here talking to Dr. Matney about Amtrak passenger service.
Dr. Matney, can you tell me a little bit about your personal knowledge or your personal background with trains?
Well, I became interested in passenger trains

through our historical society here in Houston in the Gulf Coast chapter of the National Railway Historical Society back in 1970 and became formally involved by joining that society and this was right at the at the tail end of the of the passenger service just prior to Amtrak and of course one
developed a keen interest in the passenger service available because we have one or two cars in the society that we can pick on behind passenger trains and run.
So if they discontinued, we wouldn't have any way to ride our cars.
So we took a pretty keen interest in the passenger service back in those days.
And then I gravitated from that

to becoming more interested in trying to do something to help restore passenger service in the country, instead of sticking with the historical stuff like what's going on now and what can we do to help bring it about.
And I soon heard about and joined the National Association of Railway Passengers.
And it was the lobbying organization
that gathers money from its membership and used it as a formal lobbying process for Congress and to get the enabling legislation drafted and passed and to create ANTRAC.
It has been a very strong, had a very strong influence on the development of ANTRAC since ANTRAC's original law.
ANTRAC, as you know,
It's a government-developed organization which also includes private representation on its board of directors from the railroad industry itself.
So it's a mixture of government and private leadership.
Can you tell me who owns Amtrak?
Well, it is a corporation.
a supposed to be a profit corporation.
And if they can ever run the trains and make a profit, I guess it'll turn into that.
But the government is responsible for keeping it afloat.
Not too unlikely to do some things like Chrysler and Boeing and other industries.

When a company gets so large that it presents a national process that it goes out of business, well then it suddenly, as long as the company's making money, it's just great and it's a private enterprise.
But if it's large enough and it begins to lose money, well then it becomes the sad duty of the federal government to keep bailing it out.
I think that there's a companion
A companion rail adventure that the government got into by necessity, which is related to Amtrak, and that's Conrail.
Conrail started out by two huge railroads literally going bankrupt, the Penn Central and the New York, the Pennsylvania Railroad and the New York Central.
About what time was this?
Oh, this is back in the 60s.
And they...
They merged into a Penn Central, and that's always a desperation.
When two of them are in financial trouble, they get together just to amplify it.
It doesn't really solve much.
You've got to merge something that's losing with something that's winning in order to come out of how it was.
At any rate, they merged and formed Penn Central, and that didn't work.
And then the government...
took over and established a thing called Conrail, which included, I think, six or seven railroads that were Title XI situations, you know, bankruptcy, and up in the Northeast.
Now, they poured money into it, but it's very essential that they build up their tracks and their network and their systems on the main lines.
And it's hard to believe, but Conrail is now making a profit.
And I look in the future to Amtrak doing that and to get quickly to some of the issues that are really important in Amtrak's history.
It has traditionally focused on two kinds of service.
the Northeast, and everybody else.
And everybody else is long-distance traffic.
And it turns out that long-distance trains are the profit makers, not the losers.
And in the beginning, it was thought to be just the opposite.
And where you needed rail is where you had lots of people riding, even short distances.
That was the initial thought.
And the Northeast Corridor, where there are 26 trains each way each day from Washington to New York to Boston, was selected as the ideal corridor to develop.
And they did develop it.
But it has never been a profit-making thing.
And in the beginning, Amtrak was literally set up

to conduct a funeral service over the pastor's system and to sort of get it out of everybody's corporate hair and let it die a natural death and provide a good funereal service and bury the damn thing and get it out.
But it seemed to revive, unfortunately, and it flourished a bit.
And then the Northeast Corridor came in and they introduced the Metroliners and

now they have some some i i think very fast trains are up in the 120 mile an hour category and stretches of that very fast but they're losing money because the distance that people travel the tickets they can't charge enough and be competitive with with buses and with the real uh
cheap fare airline service.
They have walk-on airline service between those major cities in the Northeast.
You can just walk on an airliner and pay your $15 or whatever it is and go from Washington to New York.
No reservations, no nothing.
There's another airliner that will open its doors and you can board it 20 minutes later or whatever.
So it's just a shuttle.
That's the kind of fairs that you're in competition with.
And it's kind of unfair because a lot of the airport, a lot of the airline's operations are government funded.
All the people in the control towers, I guess you remember the controllers and their strike and all that kind of stuff.

At any rate, I think we've got two completely different systems and two completely different sets of numbers to look at, and that's the long-distance trains, which are everything outside the northeast corner and the northeast corner.
There are some short-distance trains in California that have been initiated and are running well.
but their distances are slightly longer than the ones out there.
To give you a good example, we're now thinking of changing the route structure of the Sunset Limit.
This is a train that runs at all our good cheer behind many times from New Orleans to Houston to San Antonio to El Paso on out to Los Angeles.
And the plan is to change that route both in time and where it goes.
So it'll be an overnight train in each direction from New Orleans to Houston.
And in Houston, it will go to Dallas via College Station.
So you won't have to drive your Oldsmobile home anymore.
You can get on that train.
That would be more convenient.
Wouldn't that be fun?
Yeah.
It'll go to Dallas, and then Fort Worth, and then Abilene,
Midland, Odessa, and El Paso.
San Antonio will continue to be served by the Eagle, which now goes to Austin and Fort Worth and Dallas and Texarkana and so on.
Now, those trains will meet up there.
And in addition to those two trains, which will have a meet in the Fort Worth-Dallas area every day in each direction, so you can ride up and go in either direction on the other trains,
If you wanted to, there's going to be the reinitiation of the Lone Star from Fort Worth North to Oklahoma City, maybe Tulsa, and to Kansas City and Chicago.
There's some question as to whether it'll go the old route and go up to Wichita and then Kansas City, or go over and connect to Tulsa.
Now, the thing that's interesting about that is that people say, but you're disrupting the traffic between Houston and San Antonio.
What kind of traffic do you have?
That train gets to San Antonio now at 4 in the morning in one direction and 6 in the other.
So what kind of traffic are we interfering with at that time of morning?
We're not.

Plus the fact that you don't want to make it attractive for people to ride the train on short distances because if you've got a reserved train, it blocks people from getting through tickets to go a long distance if all the seats are occupied for 100 miles or so or 200 miles or so by a bunch of people going from Houston to Dallas.
You've got to have additional cars that you put on or you've got to have another section of the train to take
to absorb that short traffic situation.
When are they thinking about?
Well, the next schedule change is April 29.
But there's some grim news in this whole situation, too.
They sent a test train down to run from Houston to Amtrak.
from Houston to Dallas via College Station.
And all that great thing was happening right in your backyard while you're going to school and you didn't understand what was happening.
It took eight and a half hours for that train to get from Houston to Dallas.
Why did it take eight and a half hours?
Track conditions primarily.
Now, I don't think city government should be left out of this thing either.
They have a tendency to slap slow orders, ostensibly for safety, so that trains can't take possession of the grade crossing at speeds in excess of 25 miles an hour or something.
They just can't do that anymore if we're going to have passengers.
We can't afford to put an overpass or an underpass
and replace all these crossings at grade level.
There's just not enough money in the world.
We've got something like 700 of them in Houston, which is more than several states have.
And you can't do that.
It's just not practical.
So people, I think, are going to have to get used to trains running a lot faster.
I would rather have them running faster.
It's a lot more convenient.
You see a freight.

coming towards you, and you're in a car, and you're coming to a crossing, if that freight is barreling along at 45 miles an hour, I think you have a tendency to sit there and wait, because it's not going to take long for the freight to pass at that speed.
But if it's creeping along at 15 to 20 to 25, your tendency is to think, hey, that's a long train.
I'm going to be here five minutes waiting for that thing to go by at that speed.
And you have a tendency to try to run the gate or get across in front of it if there is no speed.
And I think it would be much safer.
And Dallas apparently has just done that.
They've stricken their ordinances that deal with the train speeds and the railroads and the federal government, which has to approve the track conditions.
Certain speeds can be run with certain track conditions.
The better the track, the higher the speeds, up to a point.

if you have crossings there is a point which you can't go so it would make it much more reasonable to take strike out all those ordinances there are some little towns i don't know whether college bryan college station have local ordinances that that unduly restrict the speeds of trains going through there or not sure they don't have it you almost go right through that campus
Just about.
And some people get real alarmed if you're going to have a train that's going to go through there at 50 miles an hour.
Of course, I think there would be enough passenger service there that the passenger trains, which are the ones that really want to speed up, are going to be stopping at the start.
Yeah, I think you're right.
I know that the campus spreads out across both sides of the track, though that might cause a problem.
Well, we're trying, you know, in Texas to eventually come up with a triangle of good passenger service.
And that would run from Houston to Dallas, Fort Worth, to San Antonio, to Houston, and be a triangle, actually.
And to have good, high-speed trains that would service intermediate points.
You know, we've got some large population centers in between the traffic to College Station,
When certain ball games are going on, we ought to have special trains.
Why should everybody get in their own car and drive up there?
Just imagine how many people we could get
to ride a train if you had special trains in Texas.
The Longhorns are playing the Aggies at College Station.
We've got, I don't know what the estimate is, 70,000 Texas X's that live in Houston.
What about the train they were thinking about, the bullet train between Houston and Dallas?
That's the one that is being planned by a private company and
it's going to take quite a bit of financing because high-speed trains have to have isolated tracks.
And they've got to get it up, and you can't have any deer ambling across or anything else.
It's got to be completely isolated.
And when you get into towns, it's usually elevated.
And that train, the train they're thinking about is...
which is the very high speed train that's made in France and is in operation in France now.
And it's capable of speeds of around 200 miles an hour, so it's a very fast train.
It would reduce train time to less than two hours from downtown Houston to downtown Dallas, for example.
And that would mean time-wise that no one would fly anymore.
Why would you fly if you're going from downtown Dallas?
The problem with that reasoning is that you have to get to downtown to get onto the train.

what kind of a how would you get down there and what would you do with what you've got down there with you know are you going to go down and have a big parking lot like we had out there i think the i think the training system of course one would one would argue well you get down there the same way that you get to the airport but i don't know if we had
downtown parking that would satisfy like we have out of the airport.
No, I think Houston won't require any station.

Well, you're talking about the development of MTA, of the mass transit and buses and whatever they're going to put in to mobilize people so they don't have to jump in their car and go park it and go do something.
So...
Public transportation both at this end and Houston and that end and Dallas have to be improved to the point where you can do it and not worry about getting from your home to down there.
What about recently when the mass transit...
The rail plan.
Yeah, the rail plan just got voted down.
What about that?

As a rail advocate, I guess I'm expected to say that I was bitterly disappointed, but I really wasn't because, first of all, I think that there are less expensive ways to build rail now that would be acceptable and rather attractive.
They're going at it with heavy rail, and that is...
That is very expensive, and I think light rail would have been better.
The major difference between heavy rail and light rail is that heavy rail is electrical.
They operate in trains that drive their power from the bottom.
They're usually a third rail that feeds the electricity to the train.
The light rail is an overhead electrical system.
And it's much easier to put up.
And the reason for that is if you can run light rail out on the ground, you can have grain crossings and all that, and your electricity is up in the air.
If you've got it on the ground, you can't have a grain crossing.
It would be electrocuted.
So it's a much more expensive way to do it.
The second reason that I wasn't too disappointed is that the rail line that they were planning didn't go anywhere.
It went to some major shopping areas like Greenwood Plaza in downtown.
And people were expected to feed in, presumably on buses which would connect to the train.
You can't even get people to make a transfer
We've got a very good bus service if you get down to it.

We've got a 31 bus that comes out here in our area, goes right down Gessner, half a block from where we're sitting, goes up to the Katy Freeway, gets on the Katy Freeway, has the express all the way downtown.
It'll outrun me if I'm in my car.
Get downtown, now I transfer.
And I transfer to the number seven bus that goes out to the medical center.
But I'm like most other people.
That transfer is time consuming.
And you get on a bus up here where you've got a seat all the way to town.
Then you get on something down there, and you're standing all the way to the medical center in rush hour times.
And it's ridiculous.
So people aren't going to do that.
What they needed to do was to set up this thing so that it connected major areas in town with the airports.
so that there would be absolutely no reason as to why you would really have to drive your car to the airport.
You could get on this thing at many different points in town.
You could get on one branch of it that went out to the Astrodome Medical Center and another branch in Greenway Plaza and all those places over there.
And they would connect downtown.
go out to Hobby in one direction and go to Intercontinental in one direction and Hobby in the other.
And be high speed so that you would just have a few stations to get on that thing.
Not a stop every two blocks like they were designing.
Because that destroys the purpose of it also.
So their traffic plan was ridiculous.
They should have maybe
A station out in the Astrodome area, another one in the medical center, and nothing until you get downtown.
They should have a Greenway Plaza, and what's the other one?
I'm always forgetting.
A big shopping center that's out beyond it.
Anyway, those two, and then downtown.
forget all this intermediate stuff.
You get from intermediate distances by bus or some other way.
Do you think that MARC can have any impact on that, on the local scene?
I think we have to because it's precisely the development of those kind of systems which would intermash with getting our high-speed train service to Dallas.
We have to have a way of collecting
people and getting them to the station and doing it fast.
Speed is a critical thing, not really cost as much as it is how much time it takes.
And if you can reduce the time, if you had a public transportation system that could get you to work faster than you can drive it, which way would you go?
Or go the fastest way.
That's right.
And if you were...
literally guaranteed a seat with a reading light so that you could do something in transit besides stand up and hold on to something and be jostling around.
There'd be no question, right?
So that's what we've got to move forward, I think, towards.
People are interested in service and convenience, and I think more than the actual cost, cost is important.
People are willing to pay a good price for a premium service.
What about the service up in the northeastern part of the country?
They have the shuttle between Washington, D.C. and New York.
Do businessmen...
In the airlines you're talking about, or I don't know if my name is correct.
In the rail service.
Rail service.
This is the northeast part of it.
Right.
And it's...
There are...
The last time I counted the schedule, they're from...
trains from Washington, D.C. to New York, there were 26 trains.
Well, let me put it this way.
In Baltimore, there are 26 trains each way, Amtrak trains, that go through Baltimore in each direction each day.
Now, they don't all go all the way to New York.
I think there's one or two that stop in Philadelphia.
Are these mainly used by the businessmen commuting?
That's right.
That's right.
Okay.
Is most of the business then with the businessmen, the daily traffic with them, or is it with the long excursion trips that used to be so popular, the cross-country vacations?
Well, we're back to our two different Amtrak systems.
The northeast corridor is mainly...
people that need to go short distances.

The number of those that have been on a long-distance train like the Crescent that have come all the way from New Orleans to Washington, D.C., and are now continuing to New York as their last leg of their long-distance trip would be a very small percentage of the total passengers that ride from Washington to New York.
The long-distance trains, virtually all the people that are on that are going a long distance.
The people that used to board are Lone Star that left here and went to Dallas and then on up to Chicago.
That train, most of the money, the revenue that came in,
to that train, an overwhelming amount, maybe 80% of the total dollars that were spent on tickets in Houston were for Chicago and Leon.
So people are riding the longer distance on those trains, that's right.
Then is there more to future in the long distance traveling?
Yes, I think there isn't any question about it.
I think we could fill
just about anything, if we got this new roof structure that I told you about here in Texas, and if it were to become daily, they haven't yet got that idea.
They're still tri-weekly.
But if that were a daily service, boy, oh, boy, I just think it would really be nice.
And it's not so attractive for you to ride from College Station to Houston.
And the reason for that is that you're going to run into slow orders when you get way outside of Houston.
In the last 35 miles, you're going to be going 20.
And it's going to take hours, and then you're going to have to go all the way downtown, and then you're going to have to come all the way back out here.
So, you know, it's not that attractive for the short distance.
It will never be that attractive for the short distances until you get the high-speed rail where you get them isolated.
But long distance, that'll be a beautiful way to go to Chicago.
It's so nice to get on a train and have some things to do, like write a report up like you're taping now and not have anybody disturb you.
You can be in the air a little longer.
sleeping room and stay there all day.
So you can come out and talk to people.
You can go to the dining party.
It's a class act.
I want to ask about some of the services that Amtrak has changed over the years.
I know they took the dining car off for a while, and I think they've put it back on.
The dining service has, first of all, when Amtrak
The Southern Pacific has always tried to go out of the passenger business, and there wasn't any doubt about it.
So at one time, they wanted to go out of business so they could follow around.
How can we discourage people from riding?
Well, we have a daily train and we're obligated to run a daily train in those days.
So what they did was to take the dining car off and put in a coin-operated eating cart where you had the machines that dispersed to different things just like you'd have in your dorm.
You've probably got some room that's got Coke machines and sandwich machines and cookie machines and candy machines and cigarette machines and all that junk.
So you can go in with your pocket full of quarters and get whatever you're going to get out of these things.
It's ridiculous.
And then they said, aha.
Now, if you'll let us go try weekly, we'll put first class service back on.
Because this is a transcontinental train.
So the ICC said, gosh, that's a great idea you have.
So now we lose our daily service, but we get our dining car back and our sleeping cars.
There weren't anything but chair cars on that thing.
Does that help?
All the way from New Orleans to Los Angeles on the chair car with Clint operating.
Boy, the Southern Pacific has really got vision.
I'll tell you.
So now they put the dining car back on and they ran their train tri-weekly.
Then the Southern thinking, ah.
They're tri-weekly.
We will go tri-weekly.
So the Crescent went tri-weekly and met, you know, had meets in New Orleans on a tri-weekly basis.
And it was, it's, the tri-weekly service is really the death knell of everything.
You just, no one is adjusted to, when does the train run?
Right.
I've got to go to a meeting, and I've got to be in Washington on Monday morning.
When does the train arrive?
When can I leave Houston to get there?
And if you don't have daily service, you're probably going to wind up there a day ahead of time, and no one's going to do it.
Or else you'll take the plane.
Or you're going to take an alternate.
That's it.
